title: Plains centaur

A **plains centaur**, C, is a type of [monster](/wiki/Monster "Monster") that appears in *[NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack")*. The plains centaur is the weakest of the [centaur](/wiki/Centaur_\(monster_class\) "Centaur (monster class)") [monster class](/wiki/Monster_class "Monster class") and the only neutral centaur of the group.

A plains centaur has a weapon attack and a kick attack.

If [chatting](/wiki/Chatting "Chatting") to a peaceful or tame plains centaur, they will "discuss hunting".

[ ]

## Contents

- [1 Generation](#Generation)

- [2 Strategy](#Strategy)
  - [2.1 As pets](#As_pets)

- [3 History](#History)

- [4 Origin](#Origin)

- [5 Variants](#Variants)

  - [5.1 EvilHack](#EvilHack)
  - [5.2 Hack'EM](#Hack.27EM)

- [6 Encyclopedia entry](#Encyclopedia_entry)

- [7 References](#References)

## Generation

Randomly generated plains centaurs may be peaceful towards [neutral](/wiki/Neutral "Neutral") characters.

Plains centaurs may appear among the hostile monsters that generate in [throne rooms](/wiki/Throne_room "Throne room"), as well the monsters randomly generated by [looting](/wiki/Looting "Looting") a [throne](/wiki/Throne "Throne") while [confused](/wiki/Confused "Confused") and carrying gold (provided there is no [chest](/wiki/Chest "Chest") on the level).[\[1\]](#cite_note-1)

Four [statues](/wiki/Statue "Statue") of plains centaurs are featured on [the Oracle level](/wiki/Oracle_\(level\) "Oracle (level)").

Plains centaurs appear among the random C that are part of the first [quest](/wiki/Quest "Quest") monster class for [Rangers](/wiki/Ranger "Ranger") and make up 24⁄175 of the monsters that are randomly generated on the [Ranger quest](/wiki/Ranger_quest "Ranger quest"); six plains centaurs are placed randomly across the home level at level creation. They also appear among the random C that are part of the second quest monster class for [Tourists](/wiki/Tourist "Tourist") and make up 6⁄175 of the monsters that are randomly generated on the [Tourist quest](/wiki/Tourist_quest "Tourist quest").

Plains centaurs have a 1⁄2 chance of [being generated with](/wiki/Monster_starting_inventory "Monster starting inventory") a [crossbow](/wiki/Crossbow "Crossbow") and 3–14 [bolts](/wiki/Crossbow_bolt "Crossbow bolt").[\[2\]](#cite_note-2)

## Strategy

Though not as strong as [forest](/wiki/Forest_centaur "Forest centaur") or [mountain centaurs](/wiki/Mountain_centaur "Mountain centaur"), hostile plains centaurs are still quite vicious to deal with due to the combination of their 18 [speed](/wiki/Speed "Speed"), their likelihood of a ranged weapon, and the chance of generating with a dangerous [wand](/wiki/Wand "Wand"); closing in to mitigate a ranged assault opens a character up to their melee attacks instead, which is especially rough for characters with low [HP](/wiki/HP "HP") and/or AC.

Characters with viable [ranged attacks](/wiki/Ranged_attack "Ranged attack") should make use of them in return, even if only to make melee-range combat much easier for proficient roles: magical options such as [wands](/wiki/Wand "Wand") or [spells](/wiki/Spell "Spell") are especially effective, since plains centaurs have no [MR score](/wiki/Magic_resistance_\(monster\) "Magic resistance (monster)"), and a [pet](/wiki/Pet "Pet") can also weaken the centaur enough to finish them off. Centaur [corpses](/wiki/Corpse "Corpse") are quite filling for meat-eating pets and characters alike.

### As pets

Though they are the weakest among centaurs, tame plains centaurs are still solid [steeds](/wiki/Steed "Steed"): they are one of the few mounts that can equip weapons, wear limited armor and use [unicorn horns](/wiki/Unicorn_horn "Unicorn horn") to stave off status problems, though they require [wraith](/wiki/Wraith "Wraith") corpses and potions of [gain level](/wiki/Potion_of_gain_level "Potion of gain level") to compensate for their normally-low HP caps. A [potion of speed](/wiki/Potion_of_speed "Potion of speed") or [wand of speed monster](/wiki/Wand_of_speed_monster "Wand of speed monster") will boost the centaur's speed to a stellar 24, and they can gain [reflection](/wiki/Reflection "Reflection") from amulets and shields; they can also be given unwanted neutral or unaligned [artifact weapons](/wiki/Artifact_weapon "Artifact weapon") to up their damage potential as well. Plains centaurs are much easier to keep fed, allowing non-[Knights](/wiki/Knight "Knight") to offset the [tameness](/wiki/Tameness "Tameness") decrease from each riding attempt.

Unfortunately, plains centaurs can only obtain [magic resistance](/wiki/Magic_resistance "Magic resistance") from [Magicbane](/wiki/Magicbane "Magicbane"), and otherwise can only be protected by the character's own magic resistance if they are led over a [polymorph trap](/wiki/Polymorph_trap "Polymorph trap"). Their armor limitations also restrict them to wearing [cornuthaums](/wiki/Cornuthaum "Cornuthaum") for [MC](/wiki/MC "MC"), and on top of the usual cautions for steed-riding characters, they must be kept away from [shapeshifter](/wiki/Shapeshifter "Shapeshifter") corpses if at all possible.

*The following information pertains to an upcoming version ([3.7.0](/wiki/3.7.0 "3.7.0")). If this version is now released, please verify that it is still accurate, then update the page to incorporate this information.*

Pets will no longer eat corpses that make them polymorph, unless they are starving or on the verge of becoming untame. Per [commit 8d2407f8](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/commit/8d2407f), they can also gain intrinsics from eating other corpses as well. Large humanoids such as giants and other similar monsters can now wear [mummy wrappings](/wiki/Mummy_wrapping "Mummy wrapping"), which also grant MC1; the [amulet of guarding](/wiki/Amulet_of_guarding "Amulet of guarding") also boosts MC by 2, though a different amulet may be preferred for a centaur steed.

## History

The plains centaur first appears in [NetHack 3.0.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.0.0 "NetHack 3.0.0").

## Origin

[![Wikipedia](/images/thumb/f/f8/Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png/50px-Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png)](/wiki/File:Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png "Wikipedia")

[Wikipedia](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Main_Page "wikipedia:Main Page") has an article about:

***[Centaur](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Centaur "wikipedia:Centaur")***

[![Wikipedia](/images/thumb/f/f8/Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png/50px-Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png)](/wiki/File:Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png "Wikipedia")

[Wikipedia](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Main_Page "wikipedia:Main Page") has an article about:

***[Centaur (Dungeons & Dragons)](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Centaur_\(Dungeons_%26_Dragons\) "wikipedia:Centaur (Dungeons & Dragons)")***

A centaur (Ancient Greek *κένταυρος* romanized "kéntauros", Latin *centaurus*), is a creature from Greek mythology with the upper body of a human and the lower body and legs of a horse that was said to live in the mountains of Thessaly. In one version of the myth, the centaurs were named after Centaurus, and were relatives of the legendary tribe of the Lapiths through his brother Lapithes. They are also occasionally referred to as "hippocentaurs" or as "Ixionidae" (Ancient Greek *Ἰξιονίδαι* romanized *Ixionídai*, lit. "sons of Ixion"). Female centaurs are called "centaurides", and occur more often in later antiquity.

Centaurs are thought of in many Greek myths as being as wild as untamed horses, and were said to have inhabited the region of Magnesia and Mount Pelion in Thessaly, the Foloi oak forest in Elis, and the Malean peninsula in southern Laconia. The most common theory for the centaur's origin states that they are the result of a non-riding culture (such as the Minoan and Aegeans) reacting to nomads mounted on horses, who would appear as half-man and half-animal to the uninitiated; the Aztecs are said to have had a similar misapprehension about Spanish cavalrymen. The most well known Greek centaurs are [Pholus](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pholus_\(mythology\) "wikipedia:Pholus (mythology)") and [Chiron](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chiron "wikipedia:Chiron"), who are notably much more civilized than most centaurs.

Centaurs feature in Roman mythology and were familiar figures in medieval art, bestiaries and heraldry; the work of Georges Dumézil argues for tracing centaurs back to the Indian *[gandharva](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gandharva "wikipedia:Gandharva")*, and centaur-like beings also appear in Indian and Russian folklore. The centaur eventually became a staple of modern fantasy literature and other similar media, naturally including *[Dungeons & Dragons](/wiki/Dungeons_%26_Dragons "Dungeons & Dragons")*. The centaur of *Dungeons & Dragons* is part of the original 1974 set, and also appears in the 1st Edition Monster Manual. The "sylvan" centaur is the most common, and lives in temperate forests either alone or in small tribes, while the "nomadic" centaur was more likely to be encountered in plains and steppes, where they roamed in clans. The plains centaurs of *NetHack* may be based on the latter type.

Centaurs are generally strong and proud, with nomadic centaurs being more aloof and introverted - they typically strive to find peace and balance with nature, but could act with violence when the need arose. Centaurs must eat a lot to fuel their large bodies and are known to overindulge, especially with wine and ale: a drunken centaur was much more prone to aggressive and violent behavior. Centaurs that feel a sense of wanderlust make excellent companions and occasionally even offer a ride to allies, but treat the suggestion of being used as a pack animal with derision. Sylvan centaurs are likelier to be friendly towards outsiders: as fellow forest-dwewllers, they have good relations with elves, tolerate gnomes and halflings, and generally despise humans and dwarves, though they are not actively hostile to the latter two. Conversely, nomadic centaurs much prefer the company of their own kind. Sylvan centaurs typically fight using weapons and their front hooves, while nomadic centaurs favor distance attacks and very rarely use their hooves (if ever).

## Variants

### EvilHack

In [EvilHack](/wiki/EvilHack "EvilHack"), plains centaurs and other centaurs are capable of wearing all armor except [boots](/wiki/Boots "Boots").

### Hack'EM

In [Hack'EM](/wiki/Hack%27EM "Hack'EM"), plains centaurs and other centaurs can wear all armor except boots as in EvilHack.

## Encyclopedia entry

Of all the monsters put together by the Greek imagination  
the Centaurs (Kentauroi) constituted a class in themselves.  
Despite a strong streak of sensuality, in their make-up,  
their normal behaviour was moral, and they took a kindly  
thought of man's welfare. The attempted outrage of Nessos on  
Deianeira, and that of the whole tribe of Centaurs on the  
Lapith women, are more than offset by the hospitality of  
Pholos and by the wisdom of Cheiron, physician, prophet,  
lyrist, and the instructor of Achilles. Further, the  
Centaurs were peculiar in that their nature, which united the  
body of a horse with the trunk and head of a man, involved  
an unthinkable duplication of vital organs and important  
members. So grotesque a combination seems almost un-Greek.  
These strange creatures were said to live in the caves and  
clefts of the mountains, myths associating them especially  
with the hills of Thessaly and the range of Erymanthos.

\[ Mythology of all races, Vol. 1, pp. 270-271 ]

## References

1. [↑](#cite_ref-1) [src/mkroom.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 746](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/mkroom.c#L746): *centaurs and throne rooms*
2. [↑](#cite_ref-2) [src/makemon.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 461](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/makemon.c#L461)

[![This article has been updated to reflect NetHack 3.6.7. Click here for more information.](/images/f/f7/Nh367-icon.png)](/wiki/NetHackWiki:Next_version "This article has been updated to reflect NetHack 3.6.7. Click here for more information.")

Plains centaur

From NetHackWiki

C plains centaur
Difficulty 6
Attacks Weapon 1d6 physical, Kick 1d6 physical
C plains centaur
Difficulty 6
Attacks

Weapon 1d6 physical, Kick 1d6 physical

Base level 4
Base experience 49
Speed 18
Base AC 4
Base MR 0
Alignment 0 (neutral)
Frequency (by normal means) 1 (Very rare)
Genocidable Yes
Weight 2500
Nutritional value 500
Size Large
Resistances None
Resistances conveyed None

A plains centaur:

  • has a head, a couple of arms, and a torso.
  • is omnivorous.
  • is strong.
  • likes gold.
  • can pick up weapons and food.
  • can be seen through infravision.
Reference monst.c#line1152

A plains centaur, C, is a type of monster that appears in NetHack. The plains centaur is the weakest of the centaur monster class and the only neutral centaur of the group.

A plains centaur has a weapon attack and a kick attack.

If chatting to a peaceful or tame plains centaur, they will "discuss hunting".

Contents

  • 1 Generation
  • 2 Strategy
    • 2.1 As pets
  • 3 History
  • 4 Origin
  • 5 Variants
    • 5.1 EvilHack
    • 5.2 Hack'EM
  • 6 Encyclopedia entry
  • 7 References

Generation

Randomly generated plains centaurs may be peaceful towards neutral characters.

Plains centaurs may appear among the hostile monsters that generate in throne rooms, as well the monsters randomly generated by looting a throne while confused and carrying gold (provided there is no chest on the level).[1]

Four statues of plains centaurs are featured on the Oracle level.

Plains centaurs appear among the random C that are part of the first quest monster class for Rangers and make up 24⁄175 of the monsters that are randomly generated on the Ranger quest; six plains centaurs are placed randomly across the home level at level creation. They also appear among the random C that are part of the second quest monster class for Tourists and make up 6⁄175 of the monsters that are randomly generated on the Tourist quest.

Plains centaurs have a 1⁄2 chance of being generated with a crossbow and 3–14 bolts.[2]

Strategy

Though not as strong as forest or mountain centaurs, hostile plains centaurs are still quite vicious to deal with due to the combination of their 18 speed, their likelihood of a ranged weapon, and the chance of generating with a dangerous wand; closing in to mitigate a ranged assault opens a character up to their melee attacks instead, which is especially rough for characters with low HP and/or AC.

Characters with viable ranged attacks should make use of them in return, even if only to make melee-range combat much easier for proficient roles: magical options such as wands or spells are especially effective, since plains centaurs have no MR score, and a pet can also weaken the centaur enough to finish them off. Centaur corpses are quite filling for meat-eating pets and characters alike.

As pets

Though they are the weakest among centaurs, tame plains centaurs are still solid steeds: they are one of the few mounts that can equip weapons, wear limited armor and use unicorn horns to stave off status problems, though they require wraith corpses and potions of gain level to compensate for their normally-low HP caps. A potion of speed or wand of speed monster will boost the centaur's speed to a stellar 24, and they can gain reflection from amulets and shields; they can also be given unwanted neutral or unaligned artifact weapons to up their damage potential as well. Plains centaurs are much easier to keep fed, allowing non-Knights to offset the tameness decrease from each riding attempt.

Unfortunately, plains centaurs can only obtain magic resistance from Magicbane, and otherwise can only be protected by the character's own magic resistance if they are led over a polymorph trap. Their armor limitations also restrict them to wearing cornuthaums for MC, and on top of the usual cautions for steed-riding characters, they must be kept away from shapeshifter corpses if at all possible.

The following information pertains to an upcoming version (3.7.0). If this version is now released, please verify that it is still accurate, then update the page to incorporate this information.

Pets will no longer eat corpses that make them polymorph, unless they are starving or on the verge of becoming untame. Per commit 8d2407f8, they can also gain intrinsics from eating other corpses as well. Large humanoids such as giants and other similar monsters can now wear mummy wrappings, which also grant MC1; the amulet of guarding also boosts MC by 2, though a different amulet may be preferred for a centaur steed.

History

The plains centaur first appears in NetHack 3.0.0.

Origin

Wikipedia has an article about:
Centaur
Wikipedia has an article about:
Centaur (Dungeons & Dragons)

A centaur (Ancient Greek κένταυρος romanized "kéntauros", Latin centaurus), is a creature from Greek mythology with the upper body of a human and the lower body and legs of a horse that was said to live in the mountains of Thessaly. In one version of the myth, the centaurs were named after Centaurus, and were relatives of the legendary tribe of the Lapiths through his brother Lapithes. They are also occasionally referred to as "hippocentaurs" or as "Ixionidae" (Ancient Greek Ἰξιονίδαι romanized Ixionídai, lit. "sons of Ixion"). Female centaurs are called "centaurides", and occur more often in later antiquity.

Centaurs are thought of in many Greek myths as being as wild as untamed horses, and were said to have inhabited the region of Magnesia and Mount Pelion in Thessaly, the Foloi oak forest in Elis, and the Malean peninsula in southern Laconia. The most common theory for the centaur's origin states that they are the result of a non-riding culture (such as the Minoan and Aegeans) reacting to nomads mounted on horses, who would appear as half-man and half-animal to the uninitiated; the Aztecs are said to have had a similar misapprehension about Spanish cavalrymen. The most well known Greek centaurs are Pholus and Chiron, who are notably much more civilized than most centaurs.

Centaurs feature in Roman mythology and were familiar figures in medieval art, bestiaries and heraldry; the work of Georges Dumézil argues for tracing centaurs back to the Indian gandharva, and centaur-like beings also appear in Indian and Russian folklore. The centaur eventually became a staple of modern fantasy literature and other similar media, naturally including Dungeons & Dragons. The centaur of Dungeons & Dragons is part of the original 1974 set, and also appears in the 1st Edition Monster Manual. The "sylvan" centaur is the most common, and lives in temperate forests either alone or in small tribes, while the "nomadic" centaur was more likely to be encountered in plains and steppes, where they roamed in clans. The plains centaurs of NetHack may be based on the latter type.

Centaurs are generally strong and proud, with nomadic centaurs being more aloof and introverted - they typically strive to find peace and balance with nature, but could act with violence when the need arose. Centaurs must eat a lot to fuel their large bodies and are known to overindulge, especially with wine and ale: a drunken centaur was much more prone to aggressive and violent behavior. Centaurs that feel a sense of wanderlust make excellent companions and occasionally even offer a ride to allies, but treat the suggestion of being used as a pack animal with derision. Sylvan centaurs are likelier to be friendly towards outsiders: as fellow forest-dwewllers, they have good relations with elves, tolerate gnomes and halflings, and generally despise humans and dwarves, though they are not actively hostile to the latter two. Conversely, nomadic centaurs much prefer the company of their own kind. Sylvan centaurs typically fight using weapons and their front hooves, while nomadic centaurs favor distance attacks and very rarely use their hooves (if ever).

Variants

EvilHack

In EvilHack, plains centaurs and other centaurs are capable of wearing all armor except boots.

Hack'EM

In Hack'EM, plains centaurs and other centaurs can wear all armor except boots as in EvilHack.

Encyclopedia entry

Of all the monsters put together by the Greek imagination
the Centaurs (Kentauroi) constituted a class in themselves.
Despite a strong streak of sensuality, in their make-up,
their normal behaviour was moral, and they took a kindly
thought of man's welfare. The attempted outrage of Nessos on
Deianeira, and that of the whole tribe of Centaurs on the
Lapith women, are more than offset by the hospitality of
Pholos and by the wisdom of Cheiron, physician, prophet,
lyrist, and the instructor of Achilles. Further, the
Centaurs were peculiar in that their nature, which united the
body of a horse with the trunk and head of a man, involved
an unthinkable duplication of vital organs and important
members. So grotesque a combination seems almost un-Greek.
These strange creatures were said to live in the caves and
clefts of the mountains, myths associating them especially
with the hills of Thessaly and the range of Erymanthos.

[ Mythology of all races, Vol. 1, pp. 270-271 ]

References

  1. ↑ src/mkroom.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 746: centaurs and throne rooms
  2. ↑ src/makemon.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 461

A '''plains centaur''', {{monsym|plains centaur}}, is a type of [[monster]] that appears in ''[[NetHack]]''. The plains centaur is the weakest of the [[Centaur (monster class)|centaur]] [[monster class]] and the only neutral centaur of the group.

A plains centaur has a weapon attack and a kick attack.

If [[chatting]] to a peaceful or tame plains centaur, they will "discuss hunting".

==Generation==
Randomly generated plains centaurs may be peaceful towards [[neutral]] characters.

Plains centaurs may appear among the hostile monsters that generate in [[throne room]]s, as well the monsters randomly generated by [[looting]] a [[throne]] while [[confused]] and carrying gold (provided there is no [[chest]] on the level).{{refsrc|src/mkroom.c|746|version=NetHack 3.6.7|comment=centaurs and throne rooms}}

Four [[statue]]s of plains centaurs are featured on [[Oracle (level)|the Oracle level]].

Plains centaurs appear among the random {{white|C}} that are part of the first [[quest]] monster class for [[Ranger]]s and make up {{frac|24|175}} of the monsters that are randomly generated on the [[Ranger quest]]; six plains centaurs are placed randomly across the home level at level creation. They also appear among the random {{white|C}} that are part of the second quest monster class for [[Tourist]]s and make up {{frac|6|175}} of the monsters that are randomly generated on the [[Tourist quest]].

Plains centaurs have a {{frac|2}} chance of [[Monster starting inventory|being generated with]] a [[crossbow]] and 3–14 [[crossbow bolt|bolt]]s.{{refsrc|src/makemon.c|461|nethack=3.6.7}}

==Strategy==
Though not as strong as [[Forest centaur|forest]] or [[mountain centaur]]s, hostile plains centaurs are still quite vicious to deal with due to the combination of their 18 [[speed]], their likelihood of a ranged weapon, and the chance of generating with a dangerous [[wand]]; closing in to mitigate a ranged assault opens a character up to their melee attacks instead, which is especially rough for characters with low [[HP]] and/or AC.

Characters with viable [[ranged attack]]s should make use of them in return, even if only to make melee-range combat much easier for proficient roles: magical options such as [[wand]]s or [[spell]]s are especially effective, since plains centaurs have no [[Magic resistance (monster)|MR score]], and a [[pet]] can also weaken the centaur enough to finish them off. Centaur [[corpse]]s are quite filling for meat-eating pets and characters alike.

===As pets===
Though they are the weakest among centaurs, tame plains centaurs are still solid [[steed]]s: they are one of the few mounts that can equip weapons, wear limited armor and use [[unicorn horn]]s to stave off status problems, though they require [[wraith]] corpses and potions of {{! of|gain level}} to compensate for their normally-low HP caps. A [[potion of speed]] or [[wand of speed monster]] will boost the centaur's speed to a stellar 24, and they can gain [[reflection]] from amulets and shields; they can also be given unwanted neutral or unaligned [[artifact weapon]]s to up their damage potential as well. Plains centaurs are much easier to keep fed, allowing non-[[Knight]]s to offset the [[tameness]] decrease from each riding attempt.

Unfortunately, plains centaurs can only obtain [[magic resistance]] from [[Magicbane]], and otherwise can only be protected by the character's own magic resistance if they are led over a [[polymorph trap]]. Their armor limitations also restrict them to wearing [[cornuthaum]]s for [[MC]], and on top of the usual cautions for steed-riding characters, they must be kept away from [[shapeshifter]] corpses if at all possible.

{{upcoming|3.7.0|Pets will no longer eat corpses that make them polymorph, unless they are starving or on the verge of becoming untame. Per {{commit|8d2407f}}, they can also gain intrinsics from eating other corpses as well. Large humanoids such as giants and other similar monsters can now wear [[mummy wrapping]]s, which also grant MC1; the [[amulet of guarding]] also boosts MC by 2, though a different amulet may be preferred for a centaur steed.}}

==History==
The plains centaur first appears in [[NetHack 3.0.0]].

==Origin==
{{wikipedia|Centaur}}
{{wikipedia|Centaur (Dungeons & Dragons)}}
A centaur (Ancient Greek ''κένταυρος'' romanized "kéntauros", Latin ''centaurus''), is a creature from Greek mythology with the upper body of a human and the lower body and legs of a horse that was said to live in the mountains of Thessaly. In one version of the myth, the centaurs were named after Centaurus, and were relatives of the legendary tribe of the Lapiths through his brother Lapithes. They are also occasionally referred to as "hippocentaurs" or as "Ixionidae" (Ancient Greek ''Ἰξιονίδαι'' romanized ''Ixionídai'', lit. "sons of Ixion"). Female centaurs are called "centaurides", and occur more often in later antiquity.

Centaurs are thought of in many Greek myths as being as wild as untamed horses, and were said to have inhabited the region of Magnesia and Mount Pelion in Thessaly, the Foloi oak forest in Elis, and the Malean peninsula in southern Laconia. The most common theory for the centaur's origin states that they are the result of a non-riding culture (such as the Minoan and Aegeans) reacting to nomads mounted on horses, who would appear as half-man and half-animal to the uninitiated; the Aztecs are said to have had a similar misapprehension about Spanish cavalrymen. The most well known Greek centaurs are [[Wikipedia:Pholus (mythology)|Pholus]] and [[Wikipedia:Chiron|Chiron]], who are notably much more civilized than most centaurs.

Centaurs feature in Roman mythology and were familiar figures in medieval art, bestiaries and heraldry; the work of Georges Dumézil argues for tracing centaurs back to the Indian ''[[wikipedia:Gandharva|gandharva]]'', and centaur-like beings also appear in Indian and Russian folklore. The centaur eventually became a staple of modern fantasy literature and other similar media, naturally including ''[[Dungeons & Dragons]]''. The centaur of ''Dungeons & Dragons'' is part of the original 1974 set, and also appears in the 1st Edition Monster Manual. The "sylvan" centaur is the most common, and lives in temperate forests either alone or in small tribes, while the "nomadic" centaur was more likely to be encountered in plains and steppes, where they roamed in clans. The plains centaurs of ''NetHack'' may be based on the latter type.

Centaurs are generally strong and proud, with nomadic centaurs being more aloof and introverted - they typically strive to find peace and balance with nature, but could act with violence when the need arose. Centaurs must eat a lot to fuel their large bodies and are known to overindulge, especially with wine and ale: a drunken centaur was much more prone to aggressive and violent behavior. Centaurs that feel a sense of wanderlust make excellent companions and occasionally even offer a ride to allies, but treat the suggestion of being used as a pack animal with derision. Sylvan centaurs are likelier to be friendly towards outsiders: as fellow forest-dwewllers, they have good relations with elves, tolerate gnomes and halflings, and generally despise humans and dwarves, though they are not actively hostile to the latter two. Conversely, nomadic centaurs much prefer the company of their own kind. Sylvan centaurs typically fight using weapons and their front hooves, while nomadic centaurs favor distance attacks and very rarely use their hooves (if ever).

==Variants==
===EvilHack===
In [[EvilHack]], plains centaurs and other centaurs are capable of wearing all armor except [[boots]].

===Hack'EM===
In [[Hack'EM]], plains centaurs and other centaurs can wear all armor except boots as in EvilHack.

==Encyclopedia entry==
{{encyclopedia|<poem>
Of all the monsters put together by the Greek imagination
the Centaurs (Kentauroi) constituted a class in themselves.
Despite a strong streak of sensuality, in their make-up,
their normal behaviour was moral, and they took a kindly
thought of man's welfare.  The attempted outrage of Nessos on
Deianeira, and that of the whole tribe of Centaurs on the
Lapith women, are more than offset by the hospitality of
Pholos and by the wisdom of Cheiron, physician, prophet,
lyrist, and the instructor of Achilles.  Further, the
Centaurs were peculiar in that their nature, which united the
body of a horse with the trunk and head of a man, involved
an unthinkable duplication of vital organs and important
members.  So grotesque a combination seems almost un-Greek.
These strange creatures were said to live in the caves and
clefts of the mountains, myths associating them especially
with the hills of Thessaly and the range of Erymanthos.
{{right-align|[ Mythology of all races, Vol. 1, pp. 270-271 ]}}
</poem>}}
